case_vignette: A 45-year-old-man with a past medical history of knee pain and hypertension complains of dark spot on the lower lip and hands that develop whenever he takes certain oral medications! He states the rash has been ongoing for several years, and usually begins as a pink spot with a darker brown-black center! He denies any bleeding or ulceration at the site!  Current medications includes naproxen, multivitamins, and metoprolol!   Physical examination reveals a well demarcated red-purple patch with a darker red-violaceous center on the dorsal hands and lower lip! The patch is non-painful!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have dark spots on my lower lip and hands that appear when I take certain medications. They start as pink spots with a darker brown-black center.
What medications are you taking that you've noticed trigger these spots?
I'm not sure which specific medication is triggering the spots.
Do you have a history of any chronic illnesses?
Yes, I have a history of knee pain and hypertension.
Have you had any sun exposure recently that might have affected your skin?
No, the spots are not related to sun exposure.
Do these spots cause any itching or pain?
No, the spots are non-painful.
Do you have any family history of skin diseases or similar skin symptoms?
I didn't mention any family history of skin diseases or similar symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Fixed Drug Eruption
